summary: Fake Eeveelution - Spectreon! The Chained Pokemon. Ghost type. Evolve by trading an Eevee holding the Forgotten Chain item....
caption:
Fake Eeveelution - Spectreon!

The Chained Pokemon. Ghost type. Evolve by trading an Eevee holding the Forgotten Chain item. Ability- Rattled: Dark-, Ghost-, and Bug-type moves scare the Pokémon and boost its Speed stat. Hidden Ability- Shadow Tag: This Pokémon steps on the opposing Pokémon’s shadow to prevent it from escaping.

Spectreon are highly loyal, and take a long time to build up trust. When they trust you, they’ll let you know by allowing you to get close to the orb on their chest. 

The orb on Spectreon’s chest is theorized to contain their soul. If something happens to it, the Pokemon will die. The orb glows brighter on full moons.

summary: Dark Jolteon coming down off that hype shit. His Dark backstory is...like, he used to hate Venimoths so much he'd wait in the...
caption:
Dark Jolteon coming down off that hype shit. His Dark backstory is…like, he used to hate Venimoths so much he’d wait in the forest like a bright bug zapper and he’d kill anything in the pursuit of his “murder moths” goal. Including trainers. #pokemon #Pokemoncards #halloween #darkmemes

blog.name: inikavulpixelreviews
blog.title: Let's Talk About Pokemon!
blog.description:
Reviewing my personal opinion on every single Pokemon! Yes, all 809 of them!
(Mostly) Daily Uploads, 3 PM EST.

summary: Let’s Talk About Pokemon - The Honedge Family
title: Let’s Talk About Pokemon - The Honedge Family
body:
679: Honedge

Simply put, Honedge is another one of those Pokemon I simply fell in love with as soon as it was revealed. “Haunted floating object” is a hard thing to get wrong for me. Sadly though, my hype over Honedge deflated when I learned its official art wasn’t entirely accurate. But in actuality, it was wearing a scabbard and the actual sword itself leaves a lot to be desired. It feels strange whenever I make this complaint because it’s often that modern Pokemon are criticized for the opposite, but Honedge just looks woefully underdesigned without its scabbard. It’s actually to a point where Honedge itself feels out of place in Pokemon. Had the actual blade end of the sword been a bit more mystically designed, I probably could’ve bought Honedge more in the long-run. But I do adore how, when sheathed, the edges of the blade form a face in the scabbard’s openings. Even with “teeth.”

It’s a fair enough Steel/Ghost type and I do enjoy the ghostly sword archetype. There’s just a dumber of ways it could’ve been pulled off with better effect.

If we couldn’t just have the scabbard as the blade, why not have something like a broken blade motif? With it using ghostly energies to form the rest of its blade that’s been broken off? Making it more like a rather literal ghost of a sword, if you will. That’d also make it a lot more unique among the floating ghost sword monster archetype.

Personal Score: 8/10

Still a hefty score, it’s just a design that could’ve used another re-iteration or two to work out its kinks.

680: Doublade

As someone who’s liked Klinklang, and even loved Magneton and Vanilluxe… yeah, sorry. I kinda agree with the fans this time around. Doublade doesn’t have much going on and emanates a “we couldn’t come up with anything better” energy to it. Not that it’s all bad of course, I do like how the scabbard this time around looks like a wall-mount for two, crossed swords. But still, Honedge could’ve evolved into Aegislash more elegantly than this. Like, where did the shield come from? You could’ve explored that! Or even to borrow Bogleech’s idea, make Honedge move on from a sword to possessing a shield, or even just having a Honedge hide away in a shield, giving it something of a “cocoon” stage! It’d also line up with its stat distribution better. For whatever reason, these swords have stronger defense stats than attack stats.

Personal Score: 6/10

The wall mount thing saves it from being an outright 5/10.

681: Aegislash

Thankfully Aegislash mostly saves a line that SHOULD be fantastic but has fallen just a little short of the mark. The sword is thankfully a little less plain now, though I would still appreciate it having more ornamental detail like Honedge’s scabbard. It now has two arms, I guess the implication being the “energy” Pokemon emit from evolving that they mention every now and then melted the two swords from Doublade together to form one big greatsword.

Aegislash’s defining feature of course, is its shield. It’s a fun idea that this living sword more or less acts like a knight itself, holding a shield to defend itself and swinging itself around. Even with a stance-swapping gimmick where whenever it goes on the attack, it switches to a “form” where it’s more vulnerable but hits like a truck. Then, with the move King’s Shield, it switches back to its Defensive position where it has enough bulk to take a hit. A gameplay gimmick that could’ve been done a bit more elegantly but it’s a fun dynamic anyway.

Aegislash is like, one aspect away from being perfect. This is about as good as it gets for the living, haunted sword trope being used in a Pokemon game, but that’s about it. Not much else, other than maybe having some arms. Maybe had we gone with the shield as a cocoon thing, you could turn the two flowing fabric arms into fake butterfly wings. They already kinda look like wings while it’s in its defense mode!

Speaking of the pose of its Defense mode, I actually just now noticed this. But while it’s in its Defensive stance, it actually somewhat looks like something of a medieval kingdom’s symbol. Huh.

But at least its Pokedex entries, like all ghost types these days, is good and acceptably creepy. It seeks out powerful kings to be its master, but it’s actually seeking to be in control of the king themselves. Spooky!

Personal Score: 9/10

There’s just a tiny bit to be desired here. But still cool!

Overall:

I feel like this whole line should be perfect for me, but sadly there’s just a little weirdness in the design that could’ve been improved upon here and there. Again, I think one more trip to the drawing board could’ve given it some other visual motif to hang onto. I can like this line despite the nitpicks but dang are they annoying nitpicks.

[Archive]

Even with a stance-swapping gimmick where whenever it goes on the attack, it switches to a “form” where it’s more vulnerable but hits like a truck. Then, with the move King’s Shield, it switches back to its Defensive position where it has enough bulk to take a hit. A gameplay gimmick that could’ve been done a bit more elegantly but it’s a fun dynamic anyway.

Aegislash is like, one aspect away from being perfect. This is about as good as it gets for the living, haunted sword trope being used in a Pokemon game, but that’s about it. Not much else, other than maybe having some arms. Maybe had we gone with the shield as a cocoon thing, you could turn the two flowing fabric arms into fake butterfly wings. They already kinda look like wings while it’s in its defense mode!

Speaking of the pose of its Defense mode, I actually just now noticed this. But while it’s in its Defensive stance, it actually somewhat looks like something of a medieval kingdom’s symbol. Huh.

But at least its Pokedex entries, like all ghost types these days, is good and acceptably creepy. It seeks out powerful kings to be its master, but it’s actually seeking to be in control of the king themselves. Spooky!

Personal Score: 9/10

There’s just a tiny bit to be desired here. But still cool!

Overall:

I feel like this whole line should be perfect for me, but sadly there’s just a little weirdness in the design that could’ve been improved upon here and there. Again, I think one more trip to the drawing board could’ve given it some other visual motif to hang onto. I can like this line despite the nitpicks but dang are they annoying nitpicks.

[Archive]
trail.content:
679: Honedge

Simply put, Honedge is another one of those Pokemon I simply fell in love with as soon as it was revealed. “Haunted floating object” is a hard thing to get wrong for me. Sadly though, my hype over Honedge deflated when I learned its official art wasn’t entirely accurate. But in actuality, it was wearing a scabbard and the actual sword itself leaves a lot to be desired. It feels strange whenever I make this complaint because it’s often that modern Pokemon are criticized for the opposite, but Honedge just looks woefully underdesigned without its scabbard. It’s actually to a point where Honedge itself feels out of place in Pokemon. Had the actual blade end of the sword been a bit more mystically designed, I probably could’ve bought Honedge more in the long-run. But I do adore how, when sheathed, the edges of the blade form a face in the scabbard’s openings. Even with “teeth.”

It’s a fair enough Steel/Ghost type and I do enjoy the ghostly sword archetype. There’s just a dumber of ways it could’ve been pulled off with better effect.

If we couldn’t just have the scabbard as the blade, why not have something like a broken blade motif? With it using ghostly energies to form the rest of its blade that’s been broken off? Making it more like a rather literal ghost of a sword, if you will. That’d also make it a lot more unique among the floating ghost sword monster archetype.

Personal Score: 8/10

Still a hefty score, it’s just a design that could’ve used another re-iteration or two to work out its kinks.

680: Doublade

As someone who’s liked Klinklang, and even loved Magneton and Vanilluxe… yeah, sorry. I kinda agree with the fans this time around. Doublade doesn’t have much going on and emanates a “we couldn’t come up with anything better” energy to it. Not that it’s all bad of course, I do like how the scabbard this time around looks like a wall-mount for two, crossed swords. But still, Honedge could’ve evolved into Aegislash more elegantly than this. Like, where did the shield come from? You could’ve explored that! Or even to borrow Bogleech’s idea, make Honedge move on from a sword to possessing a shield, or even just having a Honedge hide away in a shield, giving it something of a “cocoon” stage! It’d also line up with its stat distribution better. For whatever reason, these swords have stronger defense stats than attack stats.

Personal Score: 6/10

The wall mount thing saves it from being an outright 5/10.

681: Aegislash

Thankfully Aegislash mostly saves a line that SHOULD be fantastic but has fallen just a little short of the mark. The sword is thankfully a little less plain now, though I would still appreciate it having more ornamental detail like Honedge’s scabbard. It now has two arms, I guess the implication being the “energy” Pokemon emit from evolving that they mention every now and then melted the two swords from Doublade together to form one big greatsword.

Aegislash’s defining feature of course, is its shield. It’s a fun idea that this living sword more or less acts like a knight itself, holding a shield to defend itself and swinging itself around. Even with a stance-swapping gimmick where whenever it goes on the attack, it switches to a “form” where it’s more vulnerable but hits like a truck. Then, with the move King’s Shield, it switches back to its Defensive position where it has enough bulk to take a hit. A gameplay gimmick that could’ve been done a bit more elegantly but it’s a fun dynamic anyway.

Aegislash is like, one aspect away from being perfect. This is about as good as it gets for the living, haunted sword trope being used in a Pokemon game, but that’s about it. Not much else, other than maybe having some arms. Maybe had we gone with the shield as a cocoon thing, you could turn the two flowing fabric arms into fake butterfly wings. They already kinda look like wings while it’s in its defense mode!

Speaking of the pose of its Defense mode, I actually just now noticed this. But while it’s in its Defensive stance, it actually somewhat looks like something of a medieval kingdom’s symbol. Huh.

But at least its Pokedex entries, like all ghost types these days, is good and acceptably creepy. It seeks out powerful kings to be its master, but it’s actually seeking to be in control of the king themselves. Spooky!

Personal Score: 9/10

There’s just a tiny bit to be desired here. But still cool!

Overall:

I feel like this whole line should be perfect for me, but sadly there’s just a little weirdness in the design that could’ve been improved upon here and there. Again, I think one more trip to the drawing board could’ve given it some other visual motif to hang onto. I can like this line despite the nitpicks but dang are they annoying nitpicks.

[Archive]
